I cannot stress how important this moment is.

Dems are putting members who rejected corporate campaign money on a committee overseeing Wall St.

All because: 
1. Everyday people donated to our campaigns, and
2. They started to pay attention + became activists in Congress

These legislators, under public pressure, couldn‚Äôt deliver as much for big bank lobbyists.

They had to vacate one of the most powerful committees in the House. That made a space that big banks couldn‚Äôt fill, and how we got *several* non-Corp funded members into places of power.

All of a sudden, it became harder for legislators to slip corporate-friendly legislation through committee, because people would write articles and their constituents would find out and grow upset.

As I‚Äôve said before, it‚Äôs People vs Money. We‚Äôve got people, they‚Äôve got money.

All of a sudden, normal people whose student loans were bubbling, whose mortgages were underwater, and so on, started showing up to committee hearings.

Including this guy: Monopoly Man

The idea was to show legislators that everyday people were watching.
https://t.co/YU4Bw8P1Sg

Fin Services is one of few exclusive committees.

The jargon around here is that they are the ‚Äúmoney committees,‚Äù not bc they oversee money,but bc one can fundraise from special interests by sitting on it and giving corporations a listening ear.

Until people started paying attn.

Activists zoomed in on one place in particular: the Financial Services Committee, which deals with big banks, real estate, and almost every interaction people have in dealing with their own money.

What they found was a place where big bank lobbyists were slipping in their work.

During + after the 2008 financial crisis, everyday people started to viscerally see the corrosive role of lobbyists writing in legal loopholes that allowed big banks to gamble with people‚Äôs lives and the economy as a whole.

Occupy Wall Street emerged, and activism bloomed.

I want to be very clear about how successful the work of grassroots organizers and activists have been in helping Progressives secure appointments to the powerful Financial Services Committee.

What we have built is permanent. No. Matter. What.

I have spent today criss-crossing the district my family has called home for generations. I have met strangers who knew my dad, and knew stories about my loved ones.

Almost two years ago, I started what was then a completely ‚Äòimpossible‚Äô bid for Congress.

Here‚Äôs what must be done:

We must #abolishICE. It‚Äôs very structure is about as undemocratic and authoritarian as it gets in the US.

We have to replace ICE with an updated INS-like structure that handles crime through the same court system we‚Äôve had for well over 100 years. /8

2. Immigration as Criminal Justice

If a person commits a crime, they should go through due process as outlined in our Constitution. Period.

That‚Äôs how it was until 2003. ICE changed all of that, and created an extrajudicial black-box system that has deported >10k US citizens(!)

Whenever we as US citizens agree w/ military actions like weapons deals & air strikes, or when we hop on board with trade deals like NAFTA or the TPP, we should ask ourselves:

‚ÄúAre we prepared to deal with the people who will seek refuge in the US due to our actions?‚Äù

/6

1. Immigration as foreign policy

Families do not all come to the US because they spontaneously ‚Äúfeel like it.‚Äù They also come because of global trade deals that destabilize local economies, or military interventionism, or regime changes at home.

/5

The INS forwarded crimes to the Department of Justice.

That is exactly how it should be done.

Immigration should primarily be seen through two lenses (arguably 1-2 others):

1. Foreign policy
2. Criminal justice

/4

Like warrantless wiretapping, the extrajudicial and unaccountable nature of ICE is essentially built as a maiden in waiting for authoritarian abuse of power.

In fact, the folks who panic about the idea of #abolishICE seem to forget that we had a system before it: the INS.

/3

Folks are also talking about how this isn‚Äôt just Trump.

That is true, and not new to folks familiar with US immigration. Obama deported more people than his three presidential predecessors *combined.*

But now we are seeing exactly how ICE was designed without accountability. /2

About 10 years ago I worked in Ted Kennedy‚Äôs foreign affairs/immigration constituent office.

I REGULARLY fielded calls from panicked mothers who came home to missing family members.

ICE was created in 2003 along w/ the Patriot Act. It was a weapon waiting for a tyrant.

/1

Year after year, politicians in NY promise voting reform.

Yet these promises either go forgotten or go unfunded. Why?

Many local political machines depend on low turnout to win, and expanding the vote risks a wave of real candidates taking their jobs.

In 2016, NY has the 2nd lowest primary turnout - only behind Louisiana.

New York is one of the only states in America that doesn‚Äôt allow:

- early voting
- mail-in ballots
- same day registration, nor
- open primaries

The party reg deadline is a year before primaries.

Voting is among the most essential rights of American democracy.

New York treats voting flippantly. Ex: Queens BOE used https://t.co/Za50EfvU38 to purge voter rolls.

@jackiemccaffrey I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs about taking a stand on one side or another. I‚Äôm not critiquing this particular situation, just the variance.

It‚Äôs an important workplace conversation for people to have. The difference is that gov salary is public information, corporate salaries are not.

From a profit-maximizing perspective, this is understandable.

But differences in pay are a compounding effect. The moment a lower income person accepts less for the same role (often out of desperation - they can‚Äôt hold out), that low income anchors them throughout their career.

Like most other inequality gaps, wage gaps between race or gender or poverty rarely happen consciously.

Folks don‚Äôt say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to pay the woman or the African-American less;‚Äù 

They say: ‚ÄúWhat was her previous income? How low can we go?‚Äù as opposed to ‚ÄúWhat is she worth?‚Äù

The fact that gov compensation can vary WILDLY for 2 ppl doing the same job is part of a larger unequal pay problem.
